values:
Wow, finally I can actually update this thing! Most of the internet hookups at the hostels I've been at don't let you get to the page necessary for updating livejournal for whatever reason...not to mention the fact that I've been checking email and stuff as quickly as possible since I'm paying for it. 

ANYWAY

Where to begin?

I guess I'll start with now. Right now I am in a hostel in Edinburgh, Scotland called the Castle Rock. It's right in the shadow of Edinburgh Castle and it's very cool. The common rooms look like Hogwarts and there are trippy murals all over the walls. It's 7:14 pm and Meredith and I have just gotten back from a six day backpackers tour of Scotland. Prior to that we did a five day tour of of western England and Wales with the same company, Haggis, which I HIGHLY recommend. Before THAT we were in London for about three days.

We've seen so much and met so many people...just the thought of trying to summarize all of it is very overwhelming, but I'll give you some highlights. 

One of the coolest things we saw in London was a free show outside the National Theater right by the water. It was a really nice summer night and we got a drink and watched these crazy German guys do these fire and pyrotechnic tricks and things. Very cool and slightly terrifying as things were blowing up and we were getting soaked by foam and hoses.

Our first Haggis tour was incredible, mostly because we met some amazing people, most of which were Australian (definitely a theme so far on this trip and I suspect most other people's trips as well). The constant joke on that tour was this older, single American guy who we ultimately named "The General" due to his constant need to organize and pontificate. We were going into a supermarket to buy food for a group meal we were going to cook at this farmhouse turned hostel in Wales (definitely the coolest place we've stayed so far) and he actually called roll and assigned us jobs before we went in. Unbelievable. Bath, Snowdonia, a crazy night in the Lake District, karaoke in Edinburgh, a very cute and funny Scottish guide named Rab, a totally bizarre show at the Fringe festival, drinking Crownies with the Aussies...all of it was amazing. We miss our friends from that trip a lot already, especially Kim, one of the Australian girls we got pretty close to.

Anyway, after that tour we ended up in Edinburgh and spent a day before getting on the 6 day Scotland tour. I didn't think it was possible, but our next Scottish tour guide (Davey) was even cuter and cooler. Especially when he wore a kilt- amazing. This time the bus was about 90% Australians, many of whom were very outgoing and fun. The only other American girl is from Weymouth which was kind of weird. Other than the millions of Aussies there were four Indians, one Taiwanese girl, one Kiwi, and this INSANE German couple. Some of you know about my uncle Milan...this one German guy was so much like him, it was terrifying. We so many great beautiful things like the Isle of Skye, Glencoe, Ullapool, a working Whisky distillary, this incredible hike up to a big rock called the Old Man of Storr on Skye where there was this amazing misty view over the Lochs and over the ocean to the mainland. We took a cruise on Lock Ness, got soaked in the horrible weather and rain, saw the bridge from Harry Potter...

One night we stayed in this incredible "haunted" castle in the middle of nowhere and walked to this hole in the wall pub about 15 minutes away. On the way back, the lights on the path  actually went out. So it was pitch black, with a full moon on one side and the lit-up haunted castle on the other. Meredith and I were walking with these super cool Indian newlyweds, counting on the husband, Muffi, to protect us. Of course he was scared out of his mind and was no help at all. It was pretty funny. Last night we went to a pretty cool pub in Inverness where there was traditional dancing that Meredith participated in. I took pictures of course. Today on the bus everyone sang their national anthems, mostly because I made the mistake of telling everyone I was a singer and it was their way of roping me into singing. So I sang the Star Spangled banner on a yellow bus full of Australians in the middle of Scotland today. Pretty sure that will never happen again, right?

Ok, I have no idea how much this is going to cost but I'm afraid it's going to be a lot so I'm going to sign off. If I didn't make it obvious enough, we are seriously having the time of our lives. I'll be honest though, we're beat tonight and kind of just want to find a television on which to watch an episode of the Simpsons or something. We'll see.

I think this might be my last entry for awhile. I sort of woke up one morning and felt like I'd out-grown livejournal. I think maybe it was the effort I put into the retrospective. As soon as I finished I thought, I'd be ok with never using livejournal again. Anyway, this will be it for awhile for a variety of reasons about which I won't bother going into great detail- not out of a desire to be cryptic, just because they are boring and hard to explain...not at all juicy or even mildly interesting.

I'm just getting really sick of all things "online." Facebook is the new bane of my existence. If you're looking for a really good way to feel completely un-original, cruise around facebook for awhile looking at all the hundreds of people who like exactly the same shit you like. I don't care how original you think you are- throwing in some obscure band or weird movie nobody's heard of- somebody else on facebook will say the same thing and you will both instantly cease to be hip. 

I have this theory that thousands of clones were made of this one girl somewhere, they were each given black Northface fleeces and Ugg boots and some evil mastermind set them loose on college campuses across America. It's CREEPY.

This has been a really difficult week. Despite all my preventative efforts, I got sick last weekend. I'm also trying to deal with a really annoying situation with one of my classes involving all kinds of stupid academia-type red-tape issues. It's mostly bothering me because it's one of those things where it seems like I was the irresponsible party when in reality I was a victim of bad guidance and advice on the part of advisors and the like. ANYWAY it's frustrating. 

Life on 6A has been good since the advent of the futon. Our room has become quite a hub of social activity. Futons have a way of bringing people together, don't they?

As for other big news, I'm no longer going to be a music ed. major. I've been doing a lot of thinking since getting accepted into the music performance program and I ultimately came to the conclusion I've always known I would come to. I wasn't lying when I said I wanted to teach. I do. I just want that part of my life to come later when I can teach at the college level or privately and do choral conducting that isn't high school. Also, if I don't do the double degree thing there's the possibility I will graduate a full year earlier than I would otherwise (meaning I'd graduate in 2007 like I was supposed to all along). Also, I'll be able to study abroad (probably Vienna in fall 2006) which is really important to me. 

Basically, doing the double degree would be a big mistake. I could do it, but I would be completely over-extended. I don't want to make the same mistake I made in high school. It would be stupid not to take advantage of the fact that I'm at the top school for voice in the country and squander all the resources that come with that. My voice and my attitude toward singing have come a really long way in the past two years. I think I have the opportunity to do something big and I refuse to blow that. Plus, just doing the performance degree gives me breathing room since there are fewer requirements. More time to practice, work and save money, etc. etc. 

Anyway, I'm happy with my choice but a little weirded out by how abruptly I made the decision. It's like what happened with livejournal. I just woke up one day and knew what I had to do. If anything, that gives me more confidence in the rightness of the whole thing. 

So in some ways, I'm happier than I've ever been. I'm excited. I don't feel trapped anymore. I don't feel like my life is headed in one direction and one direction only. I thought trying to do everything would give me more options, but really it was cutting them down. So I'm glad I realized that.

In other ways...things are really rough right now. Like they told my parents in pre-school, I have transition issues. I'd be the sweetest, most well-behaved kid ever while we were doing play-dough, but when we made the switch to finger paint I would totally freak out. Then after a while I'd settle into the finger paint thing and everything would be cool until it was pasta-necklace time and then the whole cycle would start again. It always takes me longer to move on. I've always been this way in my life- with little things and with big things. Like at pool parties everybody would get bored with swimming except me. I could have stayed in the pool all night but everyone else wanted to watch a movie or some shit.  

Anyway, I feel like that's what's happening here too. I'm really resisting giving up on the life I knew back in W.N. even though I don't fit in there anymore. I'm a completely different person...I don't see how it could be any other way considering everything that's happened since it all went to hell at the end of senior year. Semester break was...illuminating in that way.  Home isn't really "safe" anymore. Nowhere is "safe" anymore and I'm having trouble dealing with that. Just because it's "home" doesn't mean people are going to be any more careful with your feelings or that you're immune from getting an emotional kick in the gut from time to time. I learned that the hard way, but at least I learned it.  

So yeah, if you're curious about how I've been, I'll sum it up. I'm happy here. Things are great.  Simultaneously, I'm frustrated by the fact that there are always bumps in the road and that there probably always will be bumps in the road. I'm restless. It sucks not having a car. There's so much to do but usually we don't do anything and that bothers me. I hate being tired and bored at the same time. Vicious cycle. I'm frustrated by guys for two reasons 1) I've made the decision that I will never again pursue a guy because let's face it, it may be anti-feminist or something, but guys do the pursuing. Maybe one time in a million it works the other way around, but usually you (me) just end up making a complete fool out of yourself for no reason because you realize by the end that you don't even like this other person. As they say in "He's Just Not That Into You," there's a reason it has worked this way for thousands of years. (Oh God, am becoming Bridget Jones) 2) The problem with this resolution is that there have to be guys out there willing to pursue you. This could be a major flaw in the plan. 

Fuck it, I think I'll go read Harry Potter and have some peanut M&Ms.

Peace out for now LJ and extended LJ community. If you want to know what I'm up to, you might just have to call me.

So this post is going to be about a weird dream but DON'T STOP READING because it will be worth your while. 


This dream I had was quite long, complicated and strange but one part stands out. After seeing it advertised on television, I went to a restaurant called "Tard." It was very colorful with a pink carpet and lots of bubbly looking furniture. Everything was sort of padded, presumably because at least one member of every party eating at "Tard" was, frankly, retarded. Now, upon examining the food, I came to the conclusion that it was fare from the adjacent T.G.I. Friday's. I thought "Tard" would have some kind of special food. The fact that it didn't confused me. Looking around, I could not for the life of me figure out why this establishment was especially for people with special needs, with the possible exception of the slightly modified furniture. Still, I started feeling increasingly uncomfortable being, well, not retarded. So we left.


WHY WOULD MY BRAIN COME UP WITH THAT? With all the other stuff that's been on my mind, (mass death and destruction, the meaning of life, boys) why would it conjure up such a bizarre scenario that is, as far as I can tell, not even remotely based on anything I have experienced or even thought about in real life?


A side note- Meredith will be pleased to know I spilled not once, but twice at Friendly's last night. First it was an entire spoonful of chocolate ice cream right on the crotch. Then when I stood up to put my coat on I knocked over a glass of ice. Why? WHYYYYYYYYYY?

Is it normal to be stressed out about going to a day at the spa? Probably not. I need like, directions or something. Like instructions on how to go about the whole thing. For example, what do I wear? Also, should I not wear make-up since I'm getting a facial? I don't want to show up without make-up cause I'd like to look nice since it's a nice place but it seems like it would be stupid to wear make-up. I mean, there would probably be an opportunity to like, remove the make-up pre-facial..like wearing make-up to the gym or something...which of coruse, I've done. So really, it boils down to which is more embarrassing, showing up without make-up and looking like shit or showing up with make-up and looking like an idiot. 


What if I do something terrible...like fart during the massage. That would SO be something I would do. But like, what if I really have to and the whole massage will be ruined by me trying really hard not to fart? I can totally see that happening. 

Really though, I'm such a moron for freaking out about this. Well, and for freaking out about everything in general. I need to go to bed. 

DON'T FORGET THE YANKEE SWAP!!







(or I'll hunt you down.)

I CAN'T GET MYSELF TO STUDY. 

FOR THE LOVE OF GOD SOMEBODY HELP ME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

So I will be leaving Bloomington on Tuesday afternoon. It kinda snuck (sneeked? sneaked?) up on me. It's incredible how much I've actually done in the past two weeks. Thanksgiving feels like two months ago. It was a total blur. It will be really nice to go home knowing I have a fair amount of time stretched out ahead of me and no work hanging over my head. 


Let's see...on Wednesday night we had the big Singing Hoosiers Chimes of Christmas concert. Aside from looking absolutely hideous in the dress I had to wear, and getting a huge blister from my character shoes, it was pretty cool. The fake snow at the end was pretty badass. On Thursday at rehearsal we watched the tape of the risers falling at homecoming. I think it was Sally who made the good point that it's too bad America's Funniest Home Videos isn't still on the air...Singing Hoosiers could have won $10,000. I don't think I'll ever feel comfortable on risers ever again. 

We went Christmas shopping on Friday followed by Chili's. Parts of it were sort of a nightmare because we were (read: I was) all cranky and tired and bitchy. Still, it was a worthwhile endeavor. When we came back we watched Empire Strikes Back in the lounge and I officially became the biggest dork ever. That's actually not true. Cody and Sally completely out-dork me when it comes to Star Wars. I wouldn't have pegged either of them as big Star Wars nerds...especially Cody. He's too well-dressed and hygienic (not that Sally isn't, but I know her well enough not to be too surprised when her dorkiness shows). It's probably a good thing though, really, that I'm easily out Star Wars dorked. 

"I love you!"
"I know."

I <3 HF 4 eva!!!!!!

(What if I didn't type that for the sake of irony? Would anyone still hang out with me?)

I'm losing it. 

Top ten things I'm looking forward to at home:
1) Yankee Swap! (Ya'll better be there.)
2) Tubes of cookie dough. 
3) Shopping in Boston.
4) Wrapping presents. 
5) Baking.
6) Vegetables.
7) It's a Wonderful Life
8) Shit I can't think of anymore.
9) I mean, beside the obvious ones. 
10) Like seeing everybody and driving my car again.

Sally just said my livejournal entries are all depressing. I think that's my cue to stop writing.

Today I: 

...found out I had a negative checking account balance. 

...forgot to zip up my fly. (I should also mention this happened yesterday too. Luckily it was only for a brief period in both cases). 

...couldn't play the National Anthem on piano. 

...had at least 3 awkward encounters. 

...made what was supposed to be a 10 minute presentation a 5 minute presentation.

...accidentally made a racist comment. 

...spent 15 minutes looking for an i.d. that ended up being in my wallet all along.

...forgot my umbrella.

It is official now that I am indeed a complete idiot. I suppose I'm ok with it. I wouldn't be me without the constant spilling, losing, forgetting, and talking too much. 

I have to say though, the whole doing stupid shit all the time thing is getting a little old. 

On the bright side, there was a very attractive guy working today at B.M.S. (Big Mouth Subs for those of you not in the know) and we had a very nice interaction. The best part: I was wearing high-heeled shoes and he was still taller than me...but not like, freakishly so. More like just right so. Anyway, I guess that's what happens when I take the time to shower and put on real pants.   

Or maybe it was all in my head and I'm actually freakishly ugly and nobody's ever had the courtesy to tell me. I hope that's not the case. 

I would like to wish you all a happy Festival of Lights but I don't know how to spell it.

I come home in a week. I'm considering just sleeping from now until then and saying screw it to all the shit in between. I'm so tired. I'm running out of steam. When you can't even remember to zip your pants, you have a problem.

Another interesting week in the never-ending joke that is my life. It's like one of those really long stupid jokes that starts to piss people off so much they don't even give a shit about the punch line but they wait for it anyway and then it ends up being even more stupid than they expected. You know the kind of joke I mean. 

It's a bad idea to do the livejournal things at times like these. It's very late. For me, like drunkenness, excessive lateness and fatigue often leads to oversharing. Hopefully that won't be necessary. 

Current thoughts:

I think I'm having some sort of existential crisis. Like a whole "But what does it all MEAN??" situation. 

I'm really excited for the Christmas party. And Christmas in general. 

I want to go home so I can feel cool again. 

It's a really weird feeling to achieve something you once thought was completely impossible. Not entirely a good feeling either. Kind of scary, actually. 

I miss my old self. The optimistic, philosophical, always ready for a deep Dunkin Donuts conversation Julia of two years ago seems to be fading away to make room for a more jaded (and considerably heavier) Julia.

I'm angry with myself for watching so many romantic comedies over the course of my life. 

Despite the fact that ever-increasing weight gain and romantic movies seem to be a big part of my problem, I am counting the days until Meredith and I can eat cookie dough from the tube and watch said movies. 

Why do I get wrapped up in things so easily and so blindly? I mean, I figure it out eventually and go through the whole "Wait, what was I thinking?" process, but only after it's too late and I'm already involved whether I want to be or not. 

I think my life is at a deceptive cadence right now. I'm somewhere in the vi chord (assuming life is in a major key, which we all know it's not. Think Travis lyrics). It's like, whoa, thought you were going to I but bam! you've gone to vi. A new phrase is about to start and I have no idea how it's going to end.(This has been part of a new attempt at being more of a music nerd). 

Livejournal has started to make me feel narcissistic and childish. Sort of like, "Look at me! Look at me!" Aren't I too old for that kind of thing? I mean, all things considered, I'm a pretty successful human being. I know that. I'm where I want to be. I've worked hard and I'm working hard and I'm pretty happy with myself in the broadest sense...but I constantly need positive feedback and encouragement and reinforcement. Is everyone like that or just me? I really wish I wasn't like that. 

I just need to remember to relax and ya know, carpe diem and shit.

Blah, fuck it all. Sometimes the only thing left to do is go to sleep.

Plans for tomorrow?

Buy things for myself. 
Eat ice-cream. (Unless alcohol presents itself). 
See Garden State.

I just might do these things alone. And I just might be ok with that.

ADDENDUM: I can let a lot of character flaws in other people go, mostly because I have so many of my own and it's only fair, but one that really gets me is saying you're going to do something and not doing it. I can't handle that, especially when it has a direct effect on somebody else's life. I mean, sometimes life happens and you can't follow through and there are reasons (or you're like me and you just forget everything), but if you have no intention of doing something in the first place, don't say you're going to. It really frustrates me. Just thought I'd toss another little rant in here for flavor.

Crazy day. Crazy week, really. 

I guess I already mentioned Sarah's on Wednesday.

Thursday was Thanksgiving. It was crazy. Milan was amazing, as always. Highlights of this year include "Art can be anything. Is very Avant-garde- is, could be- dog poop!" and "Julie, you, you generation, you must start...CULTURAL REVOLUTION!" God I wish I was kidding about this stuff...

Once I was free from the fam. on Thursday night I was pleasantly surprised by the company of DAVE and JENNY which was more than awesome. Jenny and I reminisced about The Great Red Ant Incident of 199_. We went to the beach (!) and it was breathtakingly amazing. We froliced, of course. 

Friday was Andrew and then Sam's house where I got to see some more good people I haven't seen in awhile. I took a forbidden Miller Lite by accident and felt bad about it but Sam forgives me so it's cool. 

On Saturday the mother, the brother, Andrew and I had breakfast at Angie's...the classic choice. Following that we walked around Newburyport for awhile which was quite refreshing and strangely something I've never done with my mother before. 

Later on Saturday we purchased our Christmas tree- the first time in Snowden history a tree has been purchased before December. It's quite nice...not as tall as we usually have but it still looks good. It's also a little crooked, but I'm trying to look on the bright side. 

Saturday night was Sczechuan Taste and Bridget Jones 2 with the girls. I loved the movie, of course, because hello I'm a total girl...we all know this. After that we said some goodbyes at Jon's and so ended my Thanksgiving break. 

I did a lot of other crap with my family that I didn't bother mentioning...like raking leaves and shit. I love my parents...and my brother even though he was kind of a dick all weekend. The house looks really good. The grand piano is back...I have a new bed. All is well. Emma was glad to see me too and Rosie is still alive. 

Today my flight from Cincinnati to Indy was cancelled. I'll spare you the whiney details but it really was a pain in the ass. They bused (or vanned) us to Indianapolis and then I got a ride to Bloomington with some girl from IU which worked out nicely. She had a Lexus. We got Wendy's and had a very nice conversation. 

I'm tired. My head hurts. And this was a completely unnecessary re-cap.

Today was good. 

Ocean, check. 
Friends, check.  
Dunkin Donuts, check.  
Car, check.  
Family, check.  
Shaw's, check.
Emma, check. 
Shoe-less shower, check.  
Newburyport, check.  


So great to be back. 

On the other hand, a little overwhelming. My brain was on overload at Sarah's tonight seeing so many people at once. Amazing how easy it is to fall back into old feelings and drama. Gah. I really need to learn how to turn my brain off and stop thinking so damn much.  

Today (well, yesterday I suppose) is Sarah's birthday and therefore the 7 year anniversary of my friendship with Jen. Hard to believe. We've come along way from the infamous chicken coop face-off...or have we? :)

I'm used to coming home and turning on late night TV in the kitchen but it's too late even for that. I hate that college has made 3:00 a.m. a normal time to be awake. 

Not much has changed here in three months. The driveway is paved, the floor in the addition is different, the grand piano is back...that tombstone place next to Wendy's is gone, there's a new building at Port Plaza, a new yellow line in the road on Maple Street, and a new house next to the Episcopal Church...my brother has gained weight, my mother has lost weight...there's a bike path on High Street in Nport (not cool)...and the beach seems to have eroded some. Oh and the Park Lunch burnt down (sort of). 

I'm excited about food tomorrow. Delicious. I hope my aunt comes through with the corn pudding.

I'm totally losing my mind. I can't concentrate on anything. All I really have to deal with is this one stupid theory essay and my brain is completely resisting it. It's not even that difficult and it shouldn't be that time consuming but it's the only thing worth worrying about between now and stepping on the plane for home so it's psychologically challenging...I guess you could say. 


Seeing Andrew and going to Louisville was awesome. I feel really lucky to have constants in my life like that. I mean, when I met Andrew four years ago, I never would have guessed our lives would bring us to his parents kitchen table in Kentucky, finishing off a bottle of wine and talking about our new realities. But that right there is the essence of what I love about life...never having any idea where you're going to end up or who you'll be having one of those conversations with in 5, 10, 30 years. Anyway, it brought me back to myself a little bit. I forgot what an amazing comfort it is just to sit and talk to someone who knows pretty much everything about you.

Of course, the process that gets two people to that point is pretty amazing too.

ANYWAY 


I suppose now is as good a time as ever:

ATTENTION!

Because last year was such a success, it seems only appropriate to announce the...

SECOND ANNUAL YANKEE SWAP/CHRISTMAS PARTY

Where? 

78 Maple W.N.

When? 

Thursday, December 23rd, 7:00. 
(We did the 23rd last year and it seemed to work out pretty well but I'm open to other suggestions at this point).

Why? 

Because you had such an amazing fucking time last year.

Who? 

Something like 25-30 people showed up over the course of the night last year so I will be expecting no less! In other words YOU are invited. Yes, YOU. Word of mouth got people there last year so I'm counting on it working again.

But Julia, what exactly is a "yankee swap"? 

Don't worry about the exact rules. It would be annoying for me to explain. Just bring a wrapped gift ($10 maximum) and rest assured you will leave with a present of some sort. There were some really awesome gifts last year.

Intriguing, but what should I wear?

You guys didn't do very well with the festive attire rule last year. I think we can do better this time. So really it's whatever "festive attire" means to you. To me, it means dressing up a little. To you it might mean a blinking Christmas tie or some of those musical socks that play Jingle Bell Rock...it really doesn't matter. Just be festive. 

...just BE THERE.

I could not be more excited to see Andrew and go to Louisville tomorrow. My first taste of home in 3 months...(Maybe 2 and 1/2 but 3 sounds better).

I really need to work on this in-class essay shit for theory. It's the only real thing between me and Thanksgiving break. 

Today in Singing Hoosiers I started crying. I mean, it wasn't obvious. I contained myself, but you know. We were just singing the fucking Christmas Festival medley and it made me think of the orchestral version we listen to at least 500 times at my house every Christmas and out of nowhere I got all emotional. It totally came out of the blue. (*cough* PMS *cough*)

I then came home and put on some John Rutter (which immediately took me back to Drelich days) and cried some more. It actually felt really good. I've only cried one other time this semester and it was at the end of Philadelphia. That particular cry was cut short by my roommate coming in and proclaiming "Ugh, I really need to take a dump." Hilarious? Yes. Do I wish I could have continued crying? Yes. This kind of living situation is a blessing and a curse for that reason. The upside is, you're never alone. It's hard to stay depressed when you're constantly surrounded by friends. The downside is, you're never alone.

So now I'm going to watch The English Patient (what can I say, it's the masochist in me) and do some work and clean up the room.

So....

I am currently in a fantastic mood. I had a very successful audition today. Looks like I'll be doing a dual Performance/Education degree. It will be challenging but I'm really pumped. 

I've been feeling all warm and fuzzy towards my parents today. I asked my dad if he would make me breakfast on Wednesday morning when I come home (I'm flying in Tuesday night) and he was really cute about it. The conversation went something like: 

Me: So dad, will you make me breakfast on Wednesday?
Dad: Eggs with cheese and peppers?
Me: Yeah exactly! And some corn muffins?
Dad: With blueberries or without?
Me: Some with, some without?
Dad: You got it. 

It was cute. And then when I told him my audition went well he told me to go out and get myself an ice cream cone. Sometimes my parents are hilarious.

A lot of the stressful stuff I had to do this week is done with (with a couple major exceptions) so I'm considerably more relaxed. Also, I've got a lot to look forward to in the near future so that has put me in a good state of mind. 

I can't fucking wait to go home! It will be so great to see everyone, even if I have gained like, 900 lbs. since coming here. Kinda like the Freshman Fifteen...but more like the...Transfer Ton. 

You know what I'm REALLY excited about? Christmas music. 

How is it already midnight? Oh well. 

It will be nice to not think about school for a little while at home. I feel a little disconnected from myself...like I've been in this little tiny world for so long that I've lost some of myself. Maybe it's just that I'm "changing." Ha! Well, we'll see. I need a philosophical talk with Dave, a Ben Folds drive with Seth, a Barnes and Noble trip with Meredith, a Plum Island trip with Sarah, a hands-dance with Chen and Chatelyn...etc., etc.  

Ok, well that's all I got.

Must stop thinking in incomplete sentences in manner of Bridget Jones. 

It's possible my love for the Olive Garden has reached an unhealthy level. 

Only nine days until home. I have so much to do between now and then and very little motivation or energy to do it. Hence, writing in livejournal when I need to leave for class (having already skipped my first one) in about 10 minutes. 

Pretty good weekend. Tough to have a bad weekend when it involves the Olive Garden, rum, stars, and late-night Kroger's. 

Ok, really need to go to class.

I hate the alarm clock. It's a tool of Satan's...kinda like mock turtlenecks and tapered jeans. I recently had a dream in which someone I know was wearing a mock turtleneck. I don't know if I can ever look at him the same way.

Hmm didn't realize I hadn't updated since getting here (Indiana). Things have been quite busy.

So the moral of that story is that I'm considerably more relaxed now that I don't have all that crap hanging over my head. 

The only thing bothering me at the moment is the social politics of the School of Music. Basically I've committed social suicide (music school wise) for two reasons: 

a) I'm a music ed. major at the moment. Music ed. majors make up about 15% of the school's population while performance majors make up about 60%. In a nutshell, the performance majors think the ed. majors are a complete joke and they aren't very subtle about it. You wouldn't believe some of the attitudes. Unbelievable. 

b) I was accepted into the Singing Hoosiers ensemble and will probably join. The Singing Hoosiers is open by audition but music and non-music majors alike are allowed to try out (strike one). The repertoire includes (among other things) old popular standards, and showtunes (strike two). Finally, there is a small amount of choreography (strike three). So, to the snobbier sets, Singing Hoosiers is also a joke. As an ed. major I have to be in it at least one semester anyway, but even if that weren't the case, I would probably be interested. I mean, it's the most popular chorus on campus and it's relatively well-known and fun and we get to travel. I mean, they went to Whales and Scotland last year. So forgive me if I think that's kind of cool.

So long story short, I'm a little upset by the snobbery but I think I'll get over it once I find my niche. I've made a lot of very nice non-snobby friends in the school of music so it's by no means everybody. And hey I mean, some of these people are the next Metropolitan Opera singers and Carnegie Hall bound concert pianists so how could they not be snobs. At least they're snobs with the talent to back it up. There's nothing worse than a snob who actually sucks in reality (there are plenty of those here too).

Apparently I leave for Indiana in two weeks. This leads me to the inevitable, obligatory seasonal question which is, "Where the hell did summer go?" Some of my summer goals were to lose weight (of course), start actually playing my guitar, watch at least 50 of the 100 greatest movies of all time, and keep my room clean. As summer draws to a close I am approximately 5 pounds heavier, my guitar has not been out of its case, I've crossed 3 movies off my list, and my room is a mess. Well, my room is actually pretty nice still but it's gotten messy in the past couple days due to boxes and packing and stuff, so that doesn't really count. The point is, I invest way too much in summer. I do it every year. I expect way too much from it and as a result, it never delivers. I need to give summer a break. So to speak. In other words, will stop making silly summer resolutions in manner of Bridget Jones 


Thirteen days of the season were spent out west with my family. There were some great moments, new states (Utah, Idaho, Wyoming, Montana), and beautiful scenery. The spacious skies, the amber waves of grain- all fantastic. But NOTHING, be it purple mountain's majesty or otherwise, is worth 13 full days with my family. NOTHING. When I got off the plane I half expected to see a parade in my honor and headlines on all the major papers reading "Courageous local girl spends 13 days with family in middle of nowhere, lives to tell."


The next couple weeks are so full of things to do...I don't know how I'm going to handle it. Figures that after a whole summer of doing nothing it comes down to two completely packed weeks where I won't even have time to think and then BOOM Indiana. It's probably better this way. Less time to worry and freak out. 

Productivity is fun. Yesterday, for example, was a great day. I'm thinking about subtracting television and Internet from my life for a period just to see what happens. Maybe like a month or something. The only exception would be checking my email occasionally because sometimes it's important...but no livejournal, no TV, and no AIM. Especially no AIM. It pisses me off. I don't like that so much of my social interaction is electronic. 


Yes, instant messaging is convenient and makes keeping in touch very easy. I ask you this though, should it be so easy? It almost seems unnatural. One of my favorite aspects of instant messaging used to be the fact that it took away a certain level of awkwardness that could potentially exist if you were talking in person. I mean, it's easy to talk online to someone you might ordinarily feel kind of uncomfortable starting up a conversation with or also it's easier to approach someone with something online instead of starting a conflict in person. I've now come to the conclusion that this is actually a drawback. I think it's important to experience awkwardness from time to time and it's definitely better to start/resolve any conflicts in person, one reason being the fact that you can never tell what someone really means through instant messaging. 


Plus, it robs us of the experience of catching up on life events and such in person. I mean, when you finally physically hang out with someone you may not have seen in months you have nothing to say because you've said it all "online" or "read it in livejournal." That's the worst- when someone says, "Oh, did I tell you _______!" And you have to say "No, but I read it in your livejournal." Talk about a conversation killer. 


Then there's the trap that I often fall into which is taking it personally when someone mysteriously signs off in the middle of a conversation or just stops responding OR when you're online for awhile and nobody ims you. It's so middle school of me to care. If ever there was something stupid to take to heart, it would be that. 


I think my reasons for wanting to go without television need no explanation. Biggest waste of time ever. (Not that I don't enjoy it like everyone else, but you have to agree that it is a waste of time.)
